body: Fixes #868 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/884)

comment_regular_data.body:
[![CLA assistant check](https://cla-assistant.io/pull/badge/signed)](https://cla-assistant.io/TokTok/c-toxcore?pullRequest=884)
All committers have signed the CLA.
how did you determine that value?

> how did you determine that value?

I looked through my current log and found one regularity: changing the connection status of TCP-> UDP occurs at intervals of 1 second, then there is a pause of 8 seconds and everything repeats. Next, I assumed that the first UDP packet sent on the 4th second (UDP_DIRECT_TIMEOUT / 2) - is lost, and the second UDP packet sent on the 8th second does not fall into the condition 8 > 8. Therefore, on the 8th second, the status changes to TCP. At the 9th second the second UDP packet arrives and the connection status again returns to the UDP-connection. 
I decided to make a small margin for overlapping time and assigned it in 2 seconds.
Probably this problem could be solved in another way: by changing the condition '>' to '>='.
I thought the solution with a time interval overlap is more reliable.
Now within two days I do not observe a problem on two of my computers

Looks solid :+1: 

I think you should also fix the condition to `>=` additionally, even if it works it's IMO better to do it right™

> I think you should also fix the condition to >= additionally, even if it works it's IMO better to do it right™

Please clarify:
1. The condition '>=' use in conjunction with parameter UDP_DIRECT_TIMEOUT_OVERLAP?
2. Or leave only one condition '>=', and DP_DIRECT_TIMEOUT OVERLAP remove completely?
use both, while the condition probably fixes the problem most of the time, we should also fix it for very slow connections.

I did some research and got new information. 

1. The UDP packets are sent to the friend-node with the UDP_DIRECT_TIMEOUT/2 interval only until the UDP connection is not "established". After the UDP connection is "established", the confirmation packets are dispatched one time per second (this will be seen in the log below).
2. I decided to strengthen the logging to look at the intensity of the exchange of UDP packets of my client and [EchoBot](https://github.com/alexbakker/EchoBot).  EchoBot public key: 76518406... From the log you can see that the response from EchoBot can be 9 seconds, which is more than UDP_DIRECT_TIMEOUT (see entries `udp_handle_packet | PK: 76518406`). This is exactly what causes the original problem. At the same time, my client sends UDP packets to EchoBot with an interval of about 1 second (see `send_packet_to | PK: 76518406`). 
One might assume that the EchoBot is responding so slowly because of the client's high load, but the maximum latency interval is never more than 9 seconds. Therefore, I conclude that loading can be a factor, but there is something else. Do the main developers have any hypotheses about this?
I have a fear that if we accept these changes, the behavior of EchoBot may not change. Just the maximum delay interval will increase from 9 seconds to 11-12.
It would be great if the developer of the EchoBot agrees to build toxcore with this PR and conduct the testing.

> use both, while the condition probably fixes the problem most of the time, we should also fix it for very slow connections.

It is made

> @hkarel you can test it yourself. the running echobot should be exactly this code:
https://github.com/alexbakker/EchoBot
ask on the #toktok channel what toxcore version its linked against (i think Impyy is running it)

1. Yes, I can run EchoBot myself, only it will not be high-loaded. All the same, EchoBot 76518406 more than 1000 friends and about 100 simultaneously connected
2. The version of toxcore can be recognized by the command !info
3. I will try to contact Impyy...
@hkarel did you try to additionally measure packet loss to echobot? On the other hand loosing 9/10 packages seems to be extremely high, so it's maybe not the issue.

> did you try to additionally measure packet loss to echobot?

Do you mean whether all my packages have reached echobot? I do not really know how to do this. 
Yes, and that makes sense? For my client, the indicator of the "established" UDP connection  is determined only coming packets from the EchoBot. Or am I wrong?
no I don't think that's even possible, I meant with a tool like `ping`
Is it possible to deactivate the creation of a TCP of connections, so that all communication is carried out only through the UDP?

In the context of solving this problem, I need to hang up the second handler on  NET_PACKET_GET_NODES command.
I ask the main developers of toxcore to suggest a way how this can be done
@hkarel I don't really understand what you mean, can you maybe reword that sentence?

> @hkarel I don't really understand what you mean, can you maybe reword that sentence?

Now we have the NET_PACKET_GET_NODES command associated with only one handler. 
`networking_registerhandler(dht->net, NET_PACKET_GET_NODES, &handle_getnodes, dht);`
https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/7d399cedcfd20f0d91a8caf386ae3c63f4dcf285/toxcore/DHT.c#L2702

I would like to have a second handler for the NET_PACKET_GET_NODES command in the net_crypto.c module in order to be able to reset the timestamp when a new UDP packet arrives. 
See usage conn->direct_lastrecv_timev4 / conn->direct_lastrecv_timev6 in handler udp_handle_packet().
https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/7d399cedcfd20f0d91a8caf386ae3c63f4dcf285/toxcore/net_crypto.c#L2413

This task is interesting in itself, as in "C" you can usually assign only one handler. I would be interested to know the opinion of the Specialists on "C" how to assign two or more handlers.

Over the past week, I continued to investigate this problem.
@irungentoo suggested for the analyze of problem make a dump of network traffic. This gave new food for thought.

Variant 1.
To maintain the status of the UDP connection it is possible to use incoming UDP packets with the commands NET_PACKET_GET_NODES, NET_PACKET_SEND_NODES_IPV6. But for it's will need to add additional handlers for these commands (about this I asked the post above). In addition, these commands do not come often enough. So I decided to abandon this decision.

Variant 2.
I was thinking about the delay in 9 seconds. I noticed that gaps occur when UDP packets of small size (32 bytes) are sent one after another. This is an empty PACKET_ID_REQUEST command.
Then I assumed that some one of the routers holds sequential one-type small packets, and instead of sending one packet per second transmits only one packet in 8 seconds. Perhaps this behavior of the router is due to mechanisms of protection against DDoD attacks.
In order to test this hypothesis, need to send the PACKET_ID_REQUEST command every time with different sizes. To do this within the framework of the current implementation is not possible, in any case I have not found a way.
Perhaps in the future this shortcoming of the tox-network can be used to limit or block it.
As a solution option - we can enter a new command similar to PACKET_ID_REQUEST. But so that this new command performs only one action - the "support" of the UDP connection in the current state, and would not be a dual-use command as now is PACKET_ID_REQUEST.

What in the end?
Now I propose to dwell on the solution that was proposed at the very beginning, only slightly changing it.
Now the parameters MAX_NUM_SENDPACKET_TRIES and UDP_DIRECT_TIMEOUT are interconnected. 
It is how correct to connect parameters of various measurement?  Parameter MAX_NUM_SENDPACKET_ TRIES defines the number of attempts, but the parameter UDP_DIRECT_TIMEUT defines the time interval. I suggest breaking the existing dependency and making the parameter UDP_DIRECT_TIMEUT independent. Like this: 
`#define UDP_DIRECT_TIMEOUT 10` 
This solution is implemented in my last commit (6733e192cda8c89aac454705400b3883bfdcf172). 
What do you think?

> I would like to have a second handler for the NET_PACKET_GET_NODES command in the net_crypto.c

If you need a second handler, you probably need to write your own handler that then calls both sub-handlers. In C these handlers are just a function pointer, which can only accept one function.

About your theory that the packets are buffered, I think that could be possible. Do you know if we maybe need to flush the send buffer after sending such a keep alive packet?

Added mechanism for sending PACKET_ID_KEEPALIVE packets
Commit: 52da005f84df7180f640338822e07c261301368c

Review status: 0 of 3 files reviewed at latest revision, all discussions resolved, some commit checks failed.

---

*[toxcore/net_crypto.c, line 959 at r4](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/884#-LCFi_cE4E65WK3T5Zlv:-LCFi_cE4E65WK3T5Zlw:b4hnifm) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/727b8e7a5f2f1b5f87a7f533311e078196af47af/toxcore/net_crypto.c#L959)):*
> ```C
> 
>     uint32_t random_len = random_u32() % MAX_SIZE_KEEPALIVE_PACKET;
>     randombytes(data + 1, random_len);
> ```

Use toxcore/crypto_core's `random_bytes` instead of directly using libsodium.

---


*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/884)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

> Use toxcore/crypto_core's random_bytes instead of directly using libsodium. 

Ok, I'll take this into consideration

The last three days I have been testing the last solution. During this time, there was no "ping-pong" incidents of TCP/UDP switching. 
I ask to accept these changes.

Can you provide a reason for the change in L2541 (return -> continue)?

Else the change lgtm

P.S. 
I want to tell thanks of Impyy for the help in testing (he had to repeatedly rebuild the EchoBot), without him I couldn't eliminate an error.
And also to thank @irungentoo for the fact that responded to my letters
And thank @Diadlo for help in testing

commit.message:
Fix the often call of event tox_friend_connection_status

Fixes #868

Is made by:
1. Fix enumeration mechanism of Crypto_Connection instances in function send_crypto_packets()
   (this item solves the main problem);
2. Disruption of correlation between parameters of different dimensions
   (the parameters MAX_NUM_SENDPACKET_TRIES and UDP_DIRECT_TIMEOUT have different dimensions).
